peripherals

Interface PeripheralDescriptor


  • public interface PeripheralDescriptor
    Classes that implement this interface are used to provide custom behaviour to a Peripheral. Hook methods are included that allow the custom behaviours to be discovered, including #getTriggers() and #getActions(). These will be called by a higher level to discover the triggers and actions and display them to the user. As a developer, if you want to add an action or trigger, you have to make sure that it appears in these lists.
    Author:
    Paul

    • Method Detail

      • doAction

        void doAction(java.lang.String action,
            java.lang.String... arguments)
        Parse action and do something. This is where you can define custom behaviour!
        Parameters:
        action - the action to do. Compare this to the list of supported actions.
        arguments - Any extra data that may be needed.

      • getTypeID

        int getTypeID()
        Returns:
        this PeripheralDescriptors type code.

      • getTypeString

        java.lang.String getTypeString()
        Returns:
        this PeripheralDescriptors type as a String that could be displayed in the UI.

        java.lang.String getXMLString()

      • getStatus

        java.lang.String getStatus(java.lang.String statusString)
        Ask the peripheral for a status string to display in the user interface. The contents of this string will be determined by the developer.
        Parameters:
        statusString -
        Returns:

      • setDelegate

        void setDelegate(TriggerHandler delegate)
        Set a delegate to receive trigger events
        Parameters:
        delegate - a class that implements TriggerHandler.

      • setPeripheral

        void setPeripheral(Peripheral peripheral)
        Associate a Peripheral to this PeripheralDescriptor.
        Parameters:
        peripheral - a Peripheral

      • validateTrigger

        boolean validateTrigger(java.lang.String triggerID,
                      java.lang.String... arguments)
        Ensure that a particular set of Arguments is valid for a particular trigger string. If the arguments are valid, but not yet in the set of enabled triggers, they will be added.
        Parameters:
        triggerID - the ID for the particular trigger that is being checked
        arguments - A ',' separated list of Strings that are being checked. Since this parameter is a varargs, it is possible to simply call

        validateTrigger("someString")

        if you are checking a trigger that has no arguments.

        Returns:
        true if the combination of triggerID and arguments exists already, or was successfully added. Returns false if the combination of triggerID and arguments is not valid.

      • validateAction

        boolean validateAction(java.lang.String actionID,
                     java.lang.String... arguments)
        Ensure that a particular set of arguments is valid for a particular action string.
        Parameters:
        actionID - the ID for the particular action that is being checked
        arguments - the ',' separated String objects that are being checked. Since this parameter is a varargs, it is possible to simply call

        validateAction("someString")

        if you are checking an action that has no arguments.

        Returns:
        true if the combination of actionID and arguments can be called. Otherwise, returns false.

      • handlePacket

        boolean handlePacket(byte[] data)
        Handle a bundle of data that was sent from the physical peripheral. This will often result in sending a callback to the developer-supplied peripheral descriptor.
        Parameters:
        data -
        Returns:
        true if the data was successfully processed.
